channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia’s War Forces Ukrainians From Their Homes in Historic Numbers
item.description: More than 6.27 million people are estimated to be displaced inside Ukraine, posing a challenge that will loom long after the war. Most are from the east, as Moscow’s forces train their artillery on Donetsk Province.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: China Offers Women Perks for Having Babies, if They’re Married
item.description: Beijing is giving incentives to stem a demographic crisis, but its control over childbirth and its suppression of women’s rights are making it difficult for some aspiring parents to start a family.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials have been doling out tax and housing credits, educational benefits and cash to encourage women to have more children. But a marriage prerequisite is increasingly unappealing to those who prefer to parent alone.

item.title: Mass Funeral Deepens Mystery: Why Did 21 South African Teens Die in Tavern?
item.description: Survivors of the tragedy last month recounted in interviews the presence of a mysterious gas and then a crush to escape. Officials say the stampede didn’t kill them.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Zipo-zenkosi Ncokazi
item.media:description: Residents wept after laying flowers at the entrance to Enyobeni Tavern in East London, South Africa, where 21 teenagers died in the early hours of June 26.

item.title: 12 Members of a Religious Group Charged in Death of 8-Year-Old
item.description: Elizabeth Struhs of Queensland, Australia, died in January because, according to the police, she was denied medical care.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Elizabeth Struhs in an undated photo provided to The Times by her sister, Jayde Struhs, left.

item.title: China Seeks to Pre-Empt Sanctions in Case of Taiwan Clash, F.B.I. Chief Says
item.description: Looking ahead to a possible conflict, Beijing wants to shield itself from the kind of economic penalties levied against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, the F.B.I. director says.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-tank fortifications from previous conflicts line the shore in Kinmen, an island group held by Taiwan, with mainland China in the background.

item.title: A Year After President’s Murder, Haitians Keep Waiting to Hit Rock Bottom
item.description: In the year since President Jovenel Moïse was killed, the country’s despair has deepened. Gangs now vie with the government for control.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The empty streets of Port-au-Prince one morning last August.

item.title: Ethnic Killings in Ethiopia Add to Crisis
item.description: Allegations of a second recent ethnic massacre in the restive region of Oromia further destabilize a country already coping with civil war in a northern region.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A World Food Program truck carrying grain burned last month while en route to Tigray, in northern Ethiopia, the site of a devastating civil war that started nearly two years ago.

item.title: France Will Renationalize EDF
item.description: The state already has a majority stake in France’s main electricity and nuclear company. The move reflected President Emmanuel Macron’s desire to champion economic and energy sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Tricastin nuclear power plant in the commune of Saint-Paul-Trois-Châteaux, in France’s Drôme region, in June.

item.title: U.K. Live Updates: Tory Ministers Tell Boris Johnson to Go
item.description: The British prime minister is under increasing pressure to step down. More than two dozen officials in his government resigned on Wednesday, and he received a withering reception in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Boris Johnson Vows to Go On Amid Wave of Cabinet Resignations
item.description: A wave of resignations and calls for him to step down showed the prime minister’s support within his Conservative Party melting away, but he remained defiant.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson leaving No. 10 Downing Street for Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Herculean Task: Helping Millions Whose Homes Are in Ruins or Russia’s Hands
item.description: Millions of Ukrainians have fled their homes as Russia has slowly advanced in the east. Many may not have a home to go back to when the war is over.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the frontline of the war has moved, many Ukrainians who have fled have returned home. But for those from the country’s east, the prospect of returning has grown only more uncertain.

item.title: How Russia’s War in Ukraine Roiled Yandex
item.description: The decline of Yandex, the Russian version of Google, is emblematic of the economic and cultural troubles spawned by the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with Yandex's founder, Arkady Volozh, right, in 2017.

item.title: Young Politicians Seek Change, but Face Hurdles as Old as Politics
item.description: A new law allowed a record number of young people to run in local elections this year. But they face skepticism, cultural hurdles and problems as old as politics itself.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheon Seung-ah, 19, second from left, at a gathering organized by the Korea Women Parliamentarian Network in Seoul last month. In June, she became the youngest election winner in South Korea’s history.

item.title: France Brings Home French Wives of ISIS Jihadists From Syria
item.description: The country repatriated 16 women from Syria, in a move it had long ruled out. Thirty-five children, including some orphans, accompanied them.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Al Hol detention camp in northeastern Syria in 2019. France had long resisted calls to repatriate adult women, saying that it considered them “fighters” who should be tried in Syria and Iraq.

item.title: With infections surging, Cyprus reinstates an indoor mask mandate.
item.description: The mandate will be enforced with spot inspections and fines of up to 300 euros ($305) for violators.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A shopping district in central Nicosia, Cyprus, in January.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: War Displaces Millions of Ukrainians
item.description: Also, Boris Johnson battles to keep his job and Europe labels gas and nuclear energy “green.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the frontline of the war in Ukraine has moved, many who fled have returned home. But for those from the country’s east, the prospect of returning has only become more uncertain and remote.

item.title: Germany Set to Allow Bailout of Uniper, Its Largest Natural Gas Importer
item.description: Berlin and Paris are preparing bailouts as Europe braces for further cuts to gas supplies next week and economists warn of a recession.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Uniper, which runs this gas storage facility in Bavaria, could get financial relief from Germany’s Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: Johnson follows a familiar playbook in his response to the latest scandal.
item.description: The British prime minister’s blueprint for dealing with a crisis, his critics say, almost never begins, and rarely ends, with simply telling the truth.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Jessica Taylor/UK Parliament, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson speaking in the House of Commons on Wednesday.

item.title: Who Could Lead the Conservative Party if Boris Johnson Resigns?
item.description: A small group is stepping to center stage as Britain’s political crisis intensifies, including the rival Boris Johnson beat last time.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Foreign Secretary Liz Truss is one possible successor to Boris Johnson as prime minister.

item.title: ‘The Daily’ podcast looks at Brittney Griner’s detention in Russia.
Sajid Javid Addresses Parliament After Calls for Johnson’s Resignation
item.description: In explaining to Parliament why he stepped down from Boris Johnson’s government, Mr. Javid said, “Treading the tightrope between loyalty and integrity has become impossible in recent months.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Sajid Javid, Britain’s former health secretary, speaking in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: The battlefields of eastern Ukraine are largely abandoned fields and streets.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents surveying damage caused by shelling in a bazaar in Sloviansk, eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Three War Scenarios
item.description: And what will influence the outcome in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident among destroyed stores in Sloviansk, Ukraine.

item.title: Europe Calls Gas and Nuclear Energy ‘Green’
item.description: Critics say the decision is likely to reverberate beyond Europe’s borders and hamper its efforts to lead the global climate negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A nuclear power station in Civaux, France. European officials argue that gas and nuclear power are important in helping the continent move away from more damaging energy sources.

item.title: Nadhim Zahawi, the newly appointed chancellor, affirms his support for the prime minister.
item.description: Mr. Zahawi, Britain’s new top finance minister, defended Boris Johnson on Wednesday’s morning news shows, but said that his focus was on tackling inflation.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Nadhim Zahawi is Britain’s fourth chancellor of the Exchequer in three years.

item.title: Who Has Resigned So Far in Boris Johnson’s Government
item.description: A growing number of officials in Boris Johnson’s government are stepping down, adding to the pressure on the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Tess Felder
item.media:description: Will Quince, right, then a candidate in Colchester, with Mr. Johnson and Priti Patel, who is now home secretary, in 2019.

item.title: How One Restaurateur Transformed America’s Energy Industry
item.description: Charif Souki’s longshot bet on liquid natural gas, or L.N.G., paid off handsomely — and turned the United States into a leading fossil-fuel exporter.
item.dc:creator: Jake Bittle
item.media:credit: Sebastian Nevols for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charif Souki in London in June.

item.title: The Best Books to Take You Through Berlin, Germany
item.description: The German author Daniel Kehlmann, most recently of the novel “Tyll,” recommends books that explore the city’s painful past and dynamic present.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Kehlmann

item.title: Most Americans Say Life Is Starting to Return to Pre-Covid Normal, a Poll Shows
item.description: In the survey, 54 percent of adults said their lives are somewhat the same.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Subway commuters in Manhattan last month.

item.title: U.K. Markets Rise as Global Factors Outweigh Political Turmoil
item.description: The long-running trends of rising inflation, worsening energy security and a weakening growth outlook are overshadowing the sudden political upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The Bank of England expects inflation in Britain to climb above 10 percent in the fall.

item.title: Boris Johnson quickly fills the two cabinet vacancies in an effort to stabilize a government in crisis.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Nadhim Zahawai, left, became Britain’s new chancellor of the Exchequer on Tuesday. Michelle Donelan, right, was promoted into Mr. Zahawai’s former role as education secretary.

item.title: If Boris Johnson Resigned, Here’s What Could Happen Next
item.description: If Boris Johnson resigns, here is what could happen next.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Graham Brady, the chairman of a committee of Conservative backbenchers in Parliament, announcing last month that Prime Minister Boris Johnson had survived a no-confidence vote. If Mr. Johnson quits, the Conservative party would need to select the next prime minister.

item.title: The decline of Yandex, a Russia tech giant, reflects the domestic troubles stirred by the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with Yandex's founder, Arkady Volozh, right, in 2017.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Shock resignations in the British government.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain at a cabinet meeting on Tuesday with Sajid Javid, left, then the health secretary, and Rishi Sunak, third from the right, then the chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: Boris Johnson Fights to Hold Power After Cabinet Ministers Resign
item.description: Two top cabinet members resigned from the scandal-scarred British prime minister’s government. Some wondered if the master of political survival could pull off another save.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain at a cabinet meeting on Tuesday with Sajid Javid, left, then the health secretary, and Rishi Sunak, third from the right, then the chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: Boris Johnson quickly fills vacancies, including the health secretary, trying to stabilize his government in crisis.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Britain’s new chancellor of the Exchequer, Nadhim Zahawi, at Downing Street on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia’s Next Offensive
item.description: Plus Boris Johnson’s fight for political survival and Twitter’s lawsuit against India
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sloviansk was hit by shelling on Tuesday as Russia set its sights on Donetsk.

item.title: Analysis: Another loyalty test for Johnson could shine a light on a successor.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: At 10 Downing Street in London this month. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has shown little inclination to leave the corridors of power.

item.title: As Russia Moves on Another Province, Ukrainians Leave Ghost Towns Behind
item.description: Vast stretches of eastern Ukraine are now largely devoid of people and industry. If Ukraine is ever to have a vibrant postwar future, it is unlikely to sprout from these ruins.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nina Zakharenko being evacuated from her home in Bakhmut.

item.title: Palestinian Outrage After U.S. Says Journalist Was Killed by Accident
item.description: The U.S. government said Shireen Abu Akleh was likely hit by a bullet fired from Israeli military lines in the occupied West Bank, but unintentionally, fueling claims that Washington isn’t impartial.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Colleagues and friends react as the Palestinian flag-draped body of the veteran Al Jazeera journalist Shireen Abu Akleh is brought to the news channel’s office in the West Bank city of Ramallah in May.

item.title: Who Is Chris Pincher?
item.description: Chris Pincher’s actions could easily have gone unnoticed if Boris Johnson’s government hadn’t already been troubled.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Chris Pincher, a British lawmaker, at a European Union meeting in Brussels in 2020, when he was a minister in the Foreign Office.

item.title: The departures come at a perilous time for the U.K. economy.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The Bank of England expects inflation in Britain to climb above 10 percent in the fall.

item.title: Who Is Rishi Sunak?
item.description: Boris Johnson appointed Mr. Sunak chancellor, the government’s chief financial officer and often second in power only to the prime minister, in February 2020.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak arriving for a regional cabinet meeting in Stoke-on-Trent, England, in May.

item.title: U.S. Aims to Expand Export Bans on China Over Security and Human Rights
item.description: The Biden administration is applying lessons learned from controls on Russia during the Ukraine war to try to limit China’s military and technological advances.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and his aides call China the greatest long-term rival of the United States, surpassing Russia.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Wife Says the White House is Not Doing Enough
item.description: The W.N.B.A. player’s wife, Cherelle, said that she would “not be quiet anymore,” adding that Brittney Griner wrote to her family about her poor physical health.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Brittney Griner appeared at a Russian court last week, and has since written a letter asking for President Biden’s help in securing her release.

item.title: El Salvador’s Bitcoin Bet Isn’t Paying Off
item.description: It brought El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, the adulation of the tech community, but reduced scarce funds and moved the nation closer to default.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Bryan Avelar
item.media:description: President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador at an event in June to mark his third year in office.

item.title: As Russia Celebrates Gains in Eastern Ukraine, Questions Surround How the Next Offensive Will Unfold
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova, Shashank Bengali and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Russia-backed troops driving through Lysychansk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Covid Outbreak Emerges in China’s Anhui Province
item.description: The country recently began to recover from a surge that shut down Shanghai for two months.
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing on Monday in Anhui Province.

item.title: A Bluer Picture
item.description: The midterm campaigns for the House and the Senate are shaping up quite differently.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senate Democrats are starting to see the opportunity to retain the Senate after the midterms.

item.title: Reduced Testing and Reporting Blur Covid Picture in U.S.
item.description: As states report less frequently, changes in the trajectory of the virus are slower to reveal themselves.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan and Sarah Cahalan
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Durham, N.C., in May. The vast majority of positive results from popular home test kits are not included in official data, and not everyone who gets infected knows or gets tested.

item.title: U.S. veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Perry Blackburn Jr., a retired Army Special Forces lieutenant colonel who spent 34 years in uniform, last month at his home in Tampa, Fla. He has been in Ukraine training soldiers on combat.

item.title: Has Biden’s Top Diplomat in Mexico, Ken Salazar, Gone Too Far, Officials Ask?
item.description: Administration officials fear that the U.S. ambassador’s cozy relationship with the Mexican president has backfired, and may be setting back American interests in the region.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ken Salazar, the American ambassador to Mexico, at his official residence in Mexico City.

item.title: Why So Many British Workers Are On Strike
item.description: With energy costs and inflation surging, and taxes and the cost of loans increasing, British workers are demanding higher pay and going on strike with a militancy not seen in years.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Lawyers protesting last week in London outside the Central Criminal Court, also known as the Old Bailey.

item.title: Ukraine’s prime minister says rebuilding will cost $750 billion.
item.description: World leaders are mapping out the monumental effort to restore a war-battered nation.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking via video link to attendants of a conference in Lugano, Switzerland, on Monday.

item.title: ‘Get the Stretcher!’ Life and Death on Ukraine’s Front Line
item.description: On another day of scorched-earth artillery barrages in the east, a team of Ukrainian medics did their best to stabilize and assure the survivors, with the din of war all around.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s tightening grip in the Donbas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The downtown Highland Park area where a gunman opened fire yesterday.

item.title: Russia Advances Behind Brutal Barrage, but Will Its Strategy Keep Working?
item.description: The Russian and Ukrainian armies have both been badly mauled, raising questions about how long they can keep fighting as they have, particularly the outgunned Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Lysychansk last month. The city has since been taken by Russian forces.
